title: 110_s2612
content: The Act titled "Small Business Lending Stimulus Act of 2008" aims to provide economic stimulus to small businesses. The "Small Business Lending Stimulus Act of 2008" aims to reduce fees for Small Business Act loans by collecting an annual fee of up to .25 percent of the outstanding balance of the deferred participation share of the loan. The Small Business Act allows for the collection of guarantee fees based on the loan amount, ranging from 1% to 3% of the deferred participation share. In fiscal year 2008, the Administrator will reduce fees for guaranteed loans under the Small Business Act to the maximum extent possible, subject to appropriations. Additionally, for institutions, the Administrator will collect no fee in place of the usual fee under the Small Business Investment Act of 1958. In fiscal year 2008, the Administrator will reduce fees for guaranteed loans under the Small Business Act and collect no fee for certain institutions under the Small Business Investment Act of 1958. Funds will be used to reduce fees for pending loan guarantee applications until the allocated amount is spent. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal year 2008 includes specific amounts for subsections (a)(1) and (a)(2), as well as direct loans under the Microloan Program. In fiscal year 2008, funds will be allocated for reducing fees for guaranteed loans under the Small Business Act and collecting no fee for certain institutions under the Small Business Investment Act of 1958. Additionally, $10,000,000 is designated for marketing, management, and technical assistance for intermediaries making microloans under the Microloan Program. Definitions include the Small Business Administration, Administrator, and the meaning of a small business concern. SEC. 3. REFINANCING UNDER THE LOCAL DEVELOPMENT BUSINESS LOAN PROGRAM. Section 502 of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to allow for permissible debt refinancing under certain conditions, including the expansion of a small business concern, collateralized existing indebtedness, and the use of proceeds for specific purposes like acquiring land or constructing buildings. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 allows for debt refinancing under specific conditions, such as using the funds for expanding a business, acquiring land, constructing buildings, or purchasing equipment. The borrower must have been current on payments for at least 1 year before refinancing, and the new financing must offer better terms or interest rates. The refinancing cannot be used for government-guaranteed debt and must be used only for refinancing existing debt or project-related costs. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 allows for debt refinancing under specific conditions, such as using the funds for expanding a business, acquiring land, constructing buildings, or purchasing equipment. The borrower must have been current on payments for at least 1 year before refinancing, and the new financing must offer better terms or interest rates. The refinancing cannot be used for government-guaranteed debt and must be used only for refinancing existing debt or project-related costs, including costs relating to the project financed under this title.
